text:
Total was day we had been looking forward to (myself obviously for way longer than my daughters) as I had dreamed of visiting Pompeii since learning about it in elementary school. With our schedule being whatआणखी it was I planned to do three hours in Pompeii an hour for lunch and then two hours in Herculaneum. Several guides I had connected with were either booked or weren’t keen on doing both in the same day. That was until I found Ludovica on Tours by Locals. She was great to work with leading up to today and we all had a great time with her. She made it informative, interesting and fun.

We have promised on our next trip to spend more time in Naples (her home town) and to reconnect.

Also highly recommend booking a van for the day if you can, was super nice being able to just jump into an air conditioned van while others were desperately seeking shade while they waited for their bus and/or taxis.

https://www.toursbylocals.com/Naples-guide-privatetour

https://instagram.com/ludoviguida_tourguidenaples?igshid=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ==

text: I'm planning to take the bullet train from Rome to Venice. Any and all advice appreciated. I'll be in Venice for a week.

comments.comment_text: Bring food and gets lots of sleep. You will have fun in Venice!

It’s super easy. Don’t get caught by the “porters” at the Venice station. It’s a very short walk to the taxis and ferries. We went in the top class of the train, assigned seating, a snack provided. A very pleasant four hour trip. The train back might be terminating in Naples so just be aware to check the train number.
Make sure to pay for seat reservations
Make sure you check for scheduled train/rail strikes. These dates are posted online.

Just don't call it "bullet" (I think that's the Japanese version)😅
Here they're called "frecce" (arrows) or simply TAV (treno ad alta velocità, high speed train)

Italy has all kind of different foods and they are very different from the North to the middle to the south and the islands.
More remote the place is and far from touristic location more rustic it is and by rustic I mean authentic / homemade …. So less customed for turists.

I'm a foodie too, and there is just too much to try in italy. Whatever region you go to, you will find great food. It's only worth concentrating in certain cities if you want to try a typical dish invented there in particular (e.g., pesto in Genoa, real Neapolitan or fried pizza in Naples, lasagna in Bologna...), for the rest I'd say pick a destination and then look for good places there. There are dozens (literally!) of guides to food in Italy, several just for pizza (like the 50top pizza site, which has rankings for street food as well). The gambero rosso guides also include books on pastry shops, bakeries (you will love I forni in Italia!), oil, wine, gelaterie, street food, and osterie.

text:
Airbnb question-Trastevere Rome.
UPDATE: Based on everyone's responses, I called Airbnb immediately and told them I would deal with it after we leave. They ended up refunding me 30% because the listing was innacurate. The host in retaliation wrote a very bad review against me. Accusted me of leaving the place dirty, which we left so clean, we even made the beds! (I took videos) He said we left "rubbish" which we did leave one bag of garbage and recycleables? and completely ruined my reputation on Airbnb. He accused us of stealing 3 towels as well. There ended up being bugs in the couch but it was hard to see since it was black. I put a white pillow and then saw them, but they were not bedbugs, just bugs. Now I doubt we will use Airbnb again with our bad review. I would stay away from this listing if you are in the Trastevere area. Thanks everyone. At least I got a partial refund.
Just arrived. Our Airbnb listing said that breakfast was included. I’m a previous text he confirmed muffins, milk, coffee, juice and a few other things. He said it was all gone. There is coffee you can make and water. It said we have resort access nearby. There is no resort access. It said there is a washer and dryer. There is a compact washing machine and a dryer rack in the outside shed. It lists washer dryer and dryer rack. My last one had washer dryer and I specifically searched this filter. Central air is barely working in the back bedroom for my kids. My other unit is working okay. I would not have chosen this unit if I knew this and nothing else is available. What would you do?

https://www.airbnb.com/rooms/43767506?
source_impression_id=p3_1689453154_hBAqbNXmq6FzFxzG

comments.comment_text: Write to Airbnb. Write to the owner as well using Airbnb.
I hope you wrote to your host before writing here.

Contact both the host and Airbnb immediately. The host has 24 hours to resolve, but you must also notify Airbnb within the 24 hours or they will not even look at your case. Take pictures documenting EVERYTHING that does not match the description. Enjoy your vacation, but take action ASAP!
Contact airbnb because you need to report it as the property isn't as advertised

Some of this reflects cultural differences. European AC may be different than what some tourists expect. Having AC does not necessarily mean it will cool off places the way AC in the US, for example, does. My own Italian family does not like AC at all. They believe it causes sickness. When my Italian family visits our home in the summer they shiver from our AC. When we stay with them the experience is reversed. (But we each somehow manage to survive) I think it’s entirely possible that the AC anywhere in Rome will be very similar to what this place offers.

Washers and dryers also mean something completely different in Italy. That “compact” washing machine is the norm there. Living spaces are much smaller in Italy so machines are designed to fit into a small space. Energy costs are also very high so the machines are designed for energy efficiency. Some of those compact washers are actually combined washer-dryer units but because energy efficiency is a priority they take hours and hours to dry clothes. So a lot of Italians just prefer to use a drying rack.

Not including breakfast when the listing stated it was included isn’t good, but typical Italian breakfasts usually include coffee or tea and a pastry. Large breakfasts are not a thing there. Be that as it may I don’t think airbnbs typically include breakfast. Old style b and bs always include breakfast but air BnBs are a different thing.

If you feel the listing was misleading I think you should notify Airbnb immediately.

I’m sorry you’re disappointed in your accommodations.
That’s not a good way to start your stay in Rome. I hope things pick up for you soon!
Contact Airbnb support and tell them it’s not what u paid for
I'm a hotel/resort girl and never used Airbnb. Many people are asking of they checked the reviews. I'm curious to know which? Are you referring to the reviews on the Airbnb website?
Report them to AIRBNB. Im a super host and you don’t get paid right away in the event there is something amiss from either party.

Some machines are both a washer and a dryer, it’s quite surprising.. nonetheless, I didn’t miss dryers when we were there.
I would definitely ask host about the breakfast and resort access that was advertised. If no remedy, go through Airbnb
Try to use your Airbnb app for communication so it can be reviewed.
What did the reviews say?
Write a very brutally honest review
Was it a Super Host? Or Airbnb plus? Did you read the reviews? Contact Airbnb support if you have issues
Contact air bnb.
Did you read any reviews or was this person a super host?
Contact airbnb. They are accessible 24/7.
We met 4 women traveling together, they said that 1 of the bedrooms was a mattress on the floor.

I agree with Yvonne- but , going forward you MUST read ALL the reviews and look really carefully at all the photos. Choose a ‘superhost’
Good luck.

I would try to make the most of it . How long are you staying and if you want to spend your vacation looking for another place or writing emails .
You will spend little time there and I know it’s not what you were told but try to enjoy your visit outside Airbnb .Honestly we slept and showered that was it gone all day until late ,

Document Document Document. And take lots of photos...even videos. Keep a detailed contemporaneous
journal.

Sounds like you got good responses. I have not had issues with airbnb, BUT I also have very strict criteria. Filtering only superhosts with almost perfect scores and loads of people who have stayed recently. The dryer rack is what we had when we went, but I've also had dryers in Europe so that's incorrect for them to list both options. The AC issue should be addressed if one isn't working. It's the owner's job to have someone come and look at the one not working. I agree with others that the AC is much different then we have here in the US (I love my AC and can sympathize with you!). Resort access is an odd listing. Does it say on the listing what is included in the resort access? I've stayed at hotels that charge a resort fee for being central to sites, but never at an airbnb. As far as the food goes, you can find a great bakery walking distance or a grocery and grab some things for the apartment. It shouldn't be listed if not included, but what can you do?

Things have changed drastically with airbnb since COVID. I know its frustrating, but I think you reporting to airbnb and making sure they are looking into it will be your way of getting things resolved. If the guy doesn't know about the listing it makes me think maybe they are a property manager rather than the owner. I hope you can get it resolved and enjoy yourselves. Trastevere is my favorite neighborhood. I have stayed in the Vatican area if you need an airbnb recommendation.
The owner we had owns several apartments in that area. Best of luck to you. Try not to let it ruin your trip.
The more I hear about Airbnb the more I think I’ll stay in hotels. This is outrageous.
Some ARBNB’s charge for A/C with a one line disclosure on the bottom of the contract. Be ware.
You suck it up, don't let it ruin your trip, and use it as a learning experience because now you know to use hotels next time

Not that this is a great consolation but just so you know there are cleaners in most cities. I used them and I was even able to drop clothes and pick up the next day, for a fee of course. But it's worth the time it saves in my opinion
Don’t use Airbnb

Enjoy your visit don't let it be negative
And be sure to file a complaint don't waste too much time

I would use it to sleep and enjoy the rest of my trip. Walk to a little cafe and have a coffee and brioche for breakfast - it’s so cheap and a nice way to explore. I stayed in that neighborhood and hung dry my clothes and understood that even if they have ac, it’s not as strong as it is in the US. Report the other issue to Airbnb of the advertised resort access.
Recently had a bad experience with air bnb in Australia. Wouldn't use them again. Not worth the hassle.
Use less of Airbnb and more apartments.

I just wanted to comment to the people saying to only book super host listings.
I understand your point but if everybody did that no new listings would ever be rented.
As a I have just spent a year renovating my house in Sicily and last week advertised it in airbnb this is a bit worrisome to me. Obviously my goal is to be a super host so I hope I will be given the opportunity.
Reach out to the host, if you don't get a response reach out to AirBNB directly.

Message the host and express your concerns first and see what they say. Washing machine and drying rack is customary. AC in Italy is not like it is in the US (if that’s where you are from). It’s not as strong.

Report it to Airbnb.
I canceled one of my Travestere homes because of the location.

The pictures look nice on the inside but then you Google the address and see what is really around the condo/ home.
Have you contacted host and Airbnb first?

Finishing up 18 days Italy/ Austria/ Germany.
1. Washer in all units and dry racks. If they have a dryer it doesn’t really dry or takes 8 hrs so better to hang
2. US AC very different from Europe AC. Most places don’t have AC and if unit has it. Your lucky to decrease humidity and that is about it.
3. Hotels- small- if 4 people need 2 rooms. Most boutique like. Not resorts.

With above said. So far have loved the trip. I love the relaxed life of Europe. People have been great. Coffee danish in am. That is it. Late dinner. Wine every meal. Slow eating and talking. Sundays closed.
It would be nice if you shared which listing it was because I booked an Airbnb in Trastevere 🫣😂
If you decide to move, Hotel Ripa Roma is in the Trastevere section and was nice. Great breakfast.

As others have said… ac in Rome is not what we are used to here. Our abnb last month had AC but it was not very cool at all. Sometimes there is a washer but only a drying rack. If there is a dryer it takes hours. Rarely is breakfast included but if the description said it was provided then certainly it should be. I don’t mean to be discouraging but i fear your only recourse is to leave an honest review and hopefully it will help others.

Use the place to $hit, shower, and shave… then the rest of the time exploring/
enjoying Rome. Report it now, then push the issue when get back home. But for now… make the best of it and make them pay later.

I get your complaints, but that "central air is barely working" part? That sounds like normal Italian air conditioning. I'd leave that out of the complaints. That's normal washing and drying for them also.
Did the listing describe the resort, or show pictures?

We just got back and stayed in five different Airbnb‘s. All of them had great air conditioning and we actually got cold at times! Four of them had compact washing machines and just a drying rack. Only one of them included breakfast items.
Contact your host asap. The washer is correct, they don’t use American dryers, push for a partial refund for breakfast, resort amenities etc. call Airbnb they’re quite helpful.

You should make sure you have a copy of the description that you booked by as they may change it prior to you getting back home. So sorry to hear, that is not a great way to start your beautiful vacation. As someone else said just sleep / shower / shave and get out and tour the place.

We stayed in an apartment which said one bedroom apartment eith three beds. Only two beds in a tiny studio and the owner was shocked when i complained she said a studio with a bed and a sofa bed is a one bedroom apartment in rome!

Contact AirBnb immediately. They don’t release payment until guest has been in the property for 24 hours.
It’s VERY important to express your concerns to AirBnb immediately. I’m an Airbnb superhost so familiar with their policies.
Definitely contact the host too—but just want to let you know the importance of contacting AirBnb immediately.
There is no dryers in Italy it’s so hot just hang it will be dried in no time!
Were there lots of reviews?

I stayed in a villa in la spezia. The ac was great and I got cold sometimes too. I will say they were very liberal with their description of their pool. I have never seen one so small. It was the size of a tiny hot tub. I didn't know that pools could be so small, it was a joke.
Did you message the host about concerns ? What was response ?
Write it all in your review! Potential customers read those!!

I'm sorry for your experience. I'm curious if you read the reviews first or if this was a superhost? Doesn't justify the misleading info either way. But we're planning on Airb&b's also and I'm nervous about it. Wondering if reading the reviews or superhost status would have revealed these things. I'm trying to figure out how to be selective & avoid surprises like this.
As others have said what are the other reviews like and any recent reviews? And what was the star rating and is it a super host?
We quit using AirBnb for that very reason. I feel like people aren’t truthful in their reviews because the host can review you as well.
None of the reviews made mention of these inaccuracies? Are you communicating this with the alleged host/owner?
What I do, NEVER use Air bnb again! They won't do anything for you

Just a few notes: airbnb aren’t allowed to serve breakfast, unless they are recognised b&b and they have the authorisation to serve food. Some of them do it anyway because tourists expect it, but it’s not allowed and generally is not given if you rented an apartment.
However if it is written in the description ask if they can give you vouchers for a cafe in the surroundings, many do like this.
Dryers in Italy are really uncommon (electricity is expensive and the wether is warm), usually “dryer” in a description means a rack where you can hang your clothes, and with this hot I think it will be faster than an actual dryer.
AC is not powerful in Italy (and with this hot, believe me, it’s better, at least if you want to be able to walk outside all day) and is not in-built, so it will never be good as what you’re used to (except in big hotels or new apartments).
When in Rome ……
We try to only book Super Hosts , arriving in a week so hopefully all goes well. First time booking with air bnb
So many things to do in Rome . Let it go . Take it up on return . Why allow this problem to overtake your visit

I would start threatening the host with very detailed negative reviews until remedied. Sounds they got very creative wording wise to entice bookings. That's a big no no and I would start reviewing them very negatively. Unfortunately lots of shady hosts out there given the financial benefit they seek.

text: If we get to Naples by train at 9:11, would there be enough time to get on a 10:00 ferry?

comments.comment_text: Would be cutting it close as you would need to catch a taxi to get to ferry area.

We had to wait awhile in line for taxi from Naples station to ferry port. May be cutting it a bit fine…. Too far to walk with luggage.
It’s a very easy walk..but with luggage and the heat and crowds…it is cutting it close, but possible. You could always take the next ferry and sit at a cafe and have a drink in between.

Sneakers, walking shoes, sandals, water shoes - the most comfy ones and wear them in before you travel

Water shoes for hotsprings. White tennis shoes. Gold vionic sandals. One pair of flats for dinner/dresses.

I bought a pair of Taos sneakers for our upcoming trip. Wore then last night to a casino and marina bar to break them in since we would do a lot of walking. They felt great and comfortable for the amount of walking we did. Highly recommend Taos.
I travel with 2 good looking sneakers & one pair of leather sandals all have to be very very comfortable & when I go in winter I wear one pair of boots that’s it & one coat and layer🌻

rinse out at night and they dry quickly. They are cute and very light weight. I have white and navy. Had them for years

Comfortable is best, sneakers etc but bring shorts and umbrella for shade and a hand fan. The cooling towels will help so much. We are showering 3 times a day

text:
So, I’m going throughout Italy at the end of September and 1st week of October.
My question is wheather it is appropriate or customary to wear white jeans or slacks at that time of year.

comments.comment_text: Why is everyone so argumentative on this site ?
Soooooo can she wear white or nah?
Nobody cares, wear whatever is comfortable
Wear what you want 🙂 it just can be a little rainy/chilly then, so I’d pack some layers like a scarf or sweater in case!
I pretty sure the white pants only in summer rule is a thing of the past.

Umm, wear whatever is respectful and culturally appropriate for whichever event you are going to. For example, don’t wear shorts or crop tops to a church event. It’s about using and applying common sense to all and every situation.
You can wear whatever you like, their is no dress code for Italy however you must be covered for the churches, just put a kaftan over your shorts and singlet, that’s what I did.
Just remember you'll be eating.lots of pasta n pizza..not good with white pants🤣 Just wear what makes you feel comfy..and happy🙂
Hi Brenda Baskette Roane……….. hope to bump into you! It’s a small world and I am also traveling throughout Italy all of September and first week in October cheers 🥂
no one care about appropriate clothes.
No one cares or even notices
Here’s an idea- wait till you get to Italy and do a little shopping for your outfits. Italian women generally love fashion - and you might enjoy seeking out outfits uniquely Italian.
Wear what you want.
Just learned that the Rome airport mall is a treasure trove of fabulous clothing shops- and are tax free! Might think of pack sparely- and pick up some pieces in Italy.
Wow people are really mean in this post. Haven’t you heard if you can’t say anything nice then stfu
Wear what you want
Your wear what ever you like.

I visit Europe every year, different countries and different seasons. Trust me, wear what suits you more. People do not care how you dress or how you wear it unless its entering a church. You will encounter people wearing leggings, shorts, linen pants...you name it. Teke whatever you wish and enjoy!!!
If I wear white - it’s a sure thing to get red sauce on it!

No one will be looking at you. Italians for the most part just wear what they want. Just make sure you feel good and are comfortable, bring jacket or sweater that time of the year and color is insignificant

Wear whatever you like as nobody cares. As long as your shoulders/
midriff is covered when visiting churches, basilicas etc, it doesn't matter what you wear
Have fun!! ❤️
I will be there same time, first time. I appreciate being a little insecure in clothing choices. Good question and I am happy with the wear what you want answers. So many opinionated and rude people.
I plan on wearing linen, it wrinkles but cool material in summer❤️❤️
People always like to bash "the Americans " the evil Americans that support their economy with tourists dollars....and let's not forget all those nasty wars we came to aid with our boys lives

Why do people get so angry, upset, nasty and hurtful?
If the question is not to your taste…don’t respond. Simple.
I think it is only an American thing, I don’t understand the “term “don’t wear white after Labour Day” Why?
No need to worry about white, but be comfortable and bring a light cover to cover your shoulders, when going into cathedrals and churches when wearing sleeveless tops or dresses.
I don't know what you mean, we usually wear jeans and slacks
Americans always have the weirdest questions. 😂
It can still be hot in Italy in September even into October so wearing white is cooler than dark colors and perfectly acceptable.
Wear what you want
Wearing white after labor day is outdated!
Vestitevi leggero !
It’s not Iran, you can wear what you want. Don’t want to stand out? Then keep your voice down, be humble, and use manners.

Just go and enjoy yourself
That’s what’s important……cult
ure
White works!
Wear whatever but white is hard to keep clean. I travel a lot in Italy and never take white apart from a white linen shirt🌻
I wear shorts.
Italians wear whatever they want..so should everyone else.
We don’t have any rules in the UK about what to wear when, and, as I understand it, neither does Italy nor the rest of Europe.
I wear what I want and I found out that I dress similarly to people here. But everyone knows I’m American so wear what you would normally wear. Enjoy.
September is still very hot, especially south. Wear whatever you are comfortable in and enjoy the culture.
What’s the issue with the colour white and Labour Day? Is Labour Day only for blue collar workers in the US?
Do you….nobody cares, enjoy your holiday. That is all.
No, only green🙈
Just wear what you want as no one actually cares.

Why should we be offended by what you wear? 😅😅
If you bump into Roberto Cavalli maybe he could judge you, but the rest of us...we really don't care and we all wear what we want and what makes us feel comfortable.

I'm going to Italy exact same time. Have exact same thought: what about a pair of white pants? Does this make me an ignoramus? I've been extremely fortunate to have travelled, both professionally and personally, for decades. Originally from small town in the middle of nowhere on the Mississippi River, lived in India (can whip on a sari in 30 seconds), went to school in Switzerland, worked in the MIddle East and South America, and on and on and on. I've been reading up on Italy and hope to be able to take it all in. But I'm still wondering about those white pants.
SMH🤦
Labor Day only exists in US not in Italy. Light colors are still worn.
White will be just fine, will be very warm. But Sicily isn’t dirt free and they will definitely get dirty.

That's a good question. At home, I'm generally not comfortable wearing white pants in autumn, so I probably wouldn't bring them when I'm traveling at that time of year even though others may wear them and look just fine. Wear what makes you feel good and comfortable and have a wonderful time on your trip! 😊
You wear whatever you would like to wear. Italians are not all well dressed, it’s just a myth, unless you work in the fashion industry or walk in some particular streets in Milan and Rome

Wow!! Hey Brenda- did you think you would get all of these lectures when you asked a simple question?! Maybe it’s your first trip to Italy and you just want to be appropriate in every way but maybe all these experts didn’t think about that. Have a fantastic time and wear what makes you comfortable. 🍕
Best tip…. Be a respectful human being and have fun in another country.

I’m here now the only time you may need to dress conservatively is in churches and in really posh restaurants ,we are all in shorts , strappy tops in the day husband in shorts vest top or tshirt and just change into a dress or nicer shorts/chinos loose shirt etc for evening , no one here cares really ! If you are a tourist they just want your €$! Enjoy your trip
You do you, at all times, everywhere. Just remember, shoulders and knees need to be covered, whether that's white or not, when you go site seeing.
Is this question real?!
I’m bringing dark blue jeans on my trip in late September, but only because I tend to get white pants dirty.
Except in restricted dress restaurants or churches, people, including locals, dress casually. No one judges out on the street.
Possible
Of course.
There’s no after Labor Day rule anymore
Where what suits you. Nobody judges you.
The only place might be churches, the real concern is that your shoulders are covered, have a great trip, and don’t sweat the small stuff. !
Wear what you want I've never felt bound by such silly rules!
Wear white anytime! Totally acceptable and fashionable!
No one cares what you wear unless you want to enter religious buildings where you must dress modestly eg cover knees, shoulders. We don’t go by these silly rules thankfully

Wear whatever the hell you want, whoever started this trend where you should only wear this not to look like a tourist was stupid.. you’ll always stand out because of far more than what you’re wearing. Just wear whatever is comfortable on you and what you like.
no one cares what you wear.

White is good anytime. I only bring white pants if I have a washing machine at my accommodations!
I drink red wine and eat tomato sauce. And I'm always dropping some.
No dress code in Italy, only conservative dress in religious places.
That's a US custom
If in doubt wear winter white or ivory. Have fun relax.

I sincerely wish Americans would care more about Italian culture and respect to Italians instead of being so obsessed with the look an what to wear . I am from Europe living in the states 30 years . It breaks my heart on so many levels . We just came from a month in Italy and I can promise you nobody looks at you or is interested what u wear . Majority of people look at the stunning architectural miracles . Please go there with open heart small suitcase and just enjoy the most beautiful country in the world
What you basically don’t want is to stand out- try to blend in as much as possible. Unwanted attention is unwanted simply put.

text:
Hi guys,

We are currently doing a 6 week road trip around Italy.

Rome —> Siena —> Florence —> Cinque Terre —> Portofino/Rapallo —> Milan —> Lake Como (currently here) —> Dolomites —> Venice —> Puglia (region) —> Matera —> Naples

We give our car back in Naples and then have a private car to Positano —> Capri —> Amalfi Town

Question: What is the easiest and most efficient way to get from Amalfi Town back to Rome? Don’t want to pay €500 for a private vehicle lol. Any advice appreciated!

comments.comment_text: Look into a boat or a taxi to Salerno, then a train to Rome.
We took a train from Rome to Naples and it was an hour. We used a private transfer to get us from Naples to sorrento. You could just do the reverse!
Have you considered a ferry to Naples then taxi to station (they are plentiful at the ferry port) and train to Rome?
Fast train in business class from Naples to Rome is €55 pp.

From Amalfi you need to get to Salerno by bus or by taxi (the price of course will be very different!) and then you can take a high speed train to Rome (more precisely to the Roma Termini station and if you need from there to Fiumicino Airport with Leonardo train).
But if the private car that you take in Naples to Amalfi could take you back to Naples, it would be even better and you could take a high speed train from Naples to Rome and you have more options than from Salerno. 😉
Do the executive upgrade on train. Its not that bad and makes the experience much nicer
From Venice to Puglia is a pretty long trip: take a day stop in Bologna, it is on your road and it worth a visit! 😉
Ferry to Salerno then train
Take the ferry from Amalfi to Salerno. 8-10 minute walk to Salerno train station. Take fast train back to Rome. We just did this…super easy! Check ferry times before booking train tickets.
Private hire back to Naples and train to Rome. Skip Positano because it’s too crowded. See Ravello and Amalfi.

text: Real question: how do italians manage to drink hot coffee all the time in the summer???

comments.comment_text: Italians? Have you ever seen balkaneros?

we can drink it cause it's literally a shot of coffee, it doesn't warm you up

Because we drink espresso, not extra hot coffees like they do in the rest of the world
It's just a sip.
Babu!
Hispanics do the same😊, totally normal.
Same way Italian women can walk on cobblestones in high heels and not fall down. Generations of training and genetics.
Hot coffee is just espresso, in summer we usually drink Caffè freddo shakerato (iced coffee) or coffee sorbet!

text: My daughter will be studying abroad in Italy for the fall semester so about 110 days total. We currently have T-mobile for cell phone service. Does anyone have any experience using T-mobile abroad for so long and know how much it will cost us or should we switch to somethig local to Italy? The T-mobile website makes it look like it will be $5 a day to use T-mobile there.

comments.comment_text: I have T-Mobile and it’s decent there but If she’s going to be away that long it’s better for her to get a local SIM card and add it to her phone (or another phone) or your T-Mobile bill might be extremely high

I’m wondering the same thing.
I just used our free T-mobile international perk on a recent 2 week trip to Italy.

My son is doing a study abroad in Italy this Fall, and I’m wondering if there is a limit on length of usage.

I’m going to call in, see if I can get a hard answer and maybe see it in writing. I was happy with my service while out and about.
You can add unlimited international to the plan for $50 a month. We just came back & worked great so you would be looking at $200 more for that time frame which isn’t bad.

I just called T Mobile about this yesterday. My daughter will be studying abroad there in the spring. As mentioned above T Mobile has international plans so we are going to add it for $50 a month. There are lower time frame plans also.
Get a local SIM, with 10-15 euro per month you can have plenty of gigabytes for internet to stay in touch via whatsapp, and in many cities there are free WiFi spots.
I paid the $5 per day but we were only there 15 days. Call them and ask for options.
Check your plan. I'm on Magenta Max and I have unlimited data BUT they do turn down the speed. (Below)I have an Italian sim from Iliad that I use instead 150Gb of 5G for 10€/mo

I lived in Italy for 3 years straight with TMobile as my carrier. I never had any issues! Just make sure your current plan is Magenta Unlimited and they’ll be able to connect to a local provider upon landing in the country. Even better, any country they travel to will also automatically connect. The only “issue” is they won’t be able to access high speeds so you can’t stream Netflix but I never had issues using Google Maps or calling my friends and family via Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp and posting updates to Instagram. All at no extra cost!!! It’s just the cost of your regular phone bill. Costs only incur if she accepts or makes calls or you don’t have an Unlimited plan. Also, most major cities have Wi-Fi in the city center and Internet cafes where students study and work so they can keep their data off while on wifi if you’re worried about extra fees 🙂

My D just did a summer session in Florence and then I joined her at the end. We have T-Mobile. You can use T-Mobile internationally
no charge except for phone calls are .25/minute. Most just use WhatsApp etc. we added the international plan to her phone for a total of 40 days I believe and I did the 10 days on mine. It was relatively inexpensive and so easy….we didn’t want to have to depend on wifi for calls
Sim cards in italy are literally some of the cheapest on earth, just have her get an italian sim card
Either do a SIM card while there or do an ESIM on your phone. I use Airalo and pick a plan. Look at the app

We just got back yesterday from Italy. We have t mobile my husband had his phone for international phone calls it was 50 a month or it would be 25 cents a minute but it is free texting or you can download whatsapp and its free calls and FaceTime on it. My daughter and son used theirs and it worked great
I was just there T-Mobile has international data and text free and .25 a minute for phone call, I would call and double check your plan.
Get an esim. Much less expensive.
Buy an Italian Sim, most of them have a cost of about 10 euro/ month including internet/phone calls

I have T-Mobile and the magenta plan works relatively well but it’s slower than what we are use to

This is what I do (I come every year 2 months to visit family)

I had an old iPhone - I made sure it’s unlocked.
I go to the TIM store and get an Italian SIM card. You pay per month. No contracts. And it’s cheap (like 9 euros a month). I carry two phones with me lololol

If she has a newer phone with an electronic sim she can toggle back and forth and get an Italian SIM card on the same phone
Why would she want to stick to an American number, at that price? She can easily get unlimited local calls and data from around 10€ per month from local providers.
Look into their local SIM cards. Usually costs 10/20€ per month.
Have her look in to an eSim and/or Google number. She'd set up either in the states before coming over
Using T-Mobile international now. $50 for the month was the best option for us

I have t-Mobil
And I have international coverage. It’s perfect 👍
This is the message I got last week from T-Mobile when I was in Italy. I still bought an e-sim to use for faster data. For calls we used What’s App.

text:
Hi! Love reading all the tips in this group!

My husband, 19y/o son and I are visiting Italy for the first time 8/26-9/6. Flying in and out of Rome. We would love some thoughts on itinerary!

We planned to stay two nights in Rome, looking to see mainly the Colosseum, Pantheon, Spanish Steps etc.

Take the train to Florence, spend 3-4 nights. Wouldआणखी like to do bike tour to Tuscany, have more free time to wander and explore etc.

The next 3-4 nights is what we are having trouble with. Initially we planned on taking the train down south and spending time on the Amalfi coast. My dream has always been to see Pompeii which is a large part of why we were going to head down there.

Anyone have thoughts on what town we should stay in down there, or if there is a better way to spend the next 3-4 nights all together? We are open to suggestions. If we don’t go to the Amalfi coast we would just take a day trip to Pompeii. Just not sure what we should do with the next 3-4 nights after leaving Florence.

Any and all input appreciated! Thanks so much!

comments.comment_text:
I agree with the tip above. We stayed in Naples last year before our Backroads trip to The Amalfi Coast. Unfortunately, we weren’t feeling well that first day and had to cancel our tour of Naples. I want to go back and see Naples and Pompeii.
There are amazing bakeries, restaurants and sites to see in Naples.

A bike tour might be miserable. It is so insanely hot. We did a vespa tour through viator and it was amazing. We passed a couple bike tour groups and they did not seem to be enjoying themselves in the heat and hills

I agree, do a Vespa tour out of Florence. We did a Vespa wine tour last may, it was great!
For Pompeii, we stayed in Sorrento (where limoncello comes from!! And it is beautiful there.) and took the train to Pompeii. Note that there is NO shade in Pompeii. But the water from the fountains/
basins is delicious and amazingly refreshing!! Be prepared to sweat! If you can, do the night colluseum tour. We went during the day and it was stifling. But I hear the night tour is amazing . Have fun!!
I’m interested to hear more from those who have done this trip. We are planning a similar trip with same destinations. Flying in/out of Rome for two weeks.

Sorrento! There’s a train station there, you can hop on a train and do Pompeii from there, easy Peasy. We did it 7 years ago. There’s a ferry port also, so Capri is accessible ( do regret not going actually), and of course Sorrento itself is a gem.
You can take the train from Florence to Sorrento. Stay in Sorrento. Easy day trip by train to Pompeii.
I think 2 night in Rome it's too little time to see the city.
Get tickets to have Breakfast at the Vatican. It is truly a wonderful experience and you can buy your tickets in advance directly from the Vatican website.
Definately visit the Amalfi Coast. Such a magic part Italy. Specially Positano. Not sure how easy it will be to find accomadation. I am off to Positano again in September.
Stay in Sorrento as base. Take golf cart tour in Rome. Take ferry to Capri.
Positano is gorgeous and you can do a day trip to Capri.
Stay in Salerno and you can get to Naples, Pompeii and Paestrum by train. You can bus or Ferry to the Amalfi towns.
Sorrento
Do a 3 hr golf cart tour of Rome

We are basically doing the same thing in October. First Rome for 3 days, taking the train to Venice for 4 days and then Venice for 3 days. We’re going to the mountains for a day trip. Leaving Venice to head home.

Stay in sorrento. It's beautiful and you can easily get to amalfi or positano, even Ravello. You can take the circumvesuviano
to Pompeii and also to Naples for day trips.
We are planning to stay in Sorrento and do Pompei and a day trip to Positano.
I would take the train to Lake Como instead of Amalfi.

You can go to Pompei (Ercolano is awesome too) from Rome, from Florence it is much farther.
I would spend at least 4-5 days in Rome, then a couple in Naples going to see the archaeological excavations you want to see.From there I would take the train to Florence. It makes a lot more sense

Omg you are going to swelter, you will need to get out early and rest during the day and then do some night things. Pompei is amazing but I don't think I could bare it in the extreme heat. Freeze bottles of water in your freezer and take them with you, pack very light, luggage is your enemy.
Cinque Terre - stunning !

Pompeii is easy to get to from Sorrento, we spent a full day there but it wasn't in the heat. Was amazing to wander around (we didn't get a guide, just read our guide book) and envisage the lifestyle they had all those years ago. Herculaneum is supposed to be also amazing, the buildings are much better preserved than those in Pompeii but it's smaller. For me, I'd skip Florence and concentrate more south (Rome, Napoli, Pompeii, Amalfi) and keep Florence, Milan, lakes, mountains and opera in Arena Verona for a future trip.
So much more to see in Rome than Florence imo, vatican is a full day by itself.

Since you are traveling between Florence and Rome, consider somewhere in Tuscany. You would need a car to explore. Maybe Chianti region (like Panzano) or Siena, Montpulciano, Pienza, somewhere in the Val d’Orchia region. So many beautiful towns. PS stay one more night in Rome. Yes, it would be hot for a bike tour in July (I did Backroads through Tuscany a few years ago and it was one of the best trips, despite the July heat) but by the end of August you should be fine.
There is a train from Rome that goes to Pompeii. I think you need to add days to your Rome stay. You can also stay in Sorrento. It’s close to Pompeii.
Our favorite is Napoli…a 1 hour fast train from Roma. Pompeii is an easy local train ride from Napoli Centrale. Margherita pizza and Sfogliatella there.
Thanks everyone! Changed our itinerary to do 3 nights in Florence, 4 in Sorrento and last 3 in Rome. Now to start booking tickets and tours!
We will be arriving August 1st to Rome and planned 3 bases: Rome, Bologna and Sorrento. From those places spread around and Pompeii is one of our visits.

August is horribly 🥵
I would definitely consider an AC tour
You can stay in Naples for 1 night and visit Pompeii by train and then you can continue to Amalfi coast. We stayed 3 nights in Napoli and we loved it.

When we went to Italy a few years ago, we planned similarly to you since my son's two requests for the trip were the Coliseum and Pompeii. We spent a few days in Rome, then Florence, then took the train to Naples, and from there had a car drive us to Pompeii for a tour. The car then took us to the town of Amalfi, where we stayed. Amalfi was lovely, and we cabbed it over to Ravello one day to poke around. It was a lovely end to our trip.

I lived in Umbria for 15 years, there is so much to see . Some highlights:
- Gubbio, including the cable car to go up to the sanctuary
- Rasiglia and Bevagna
-Lake Trasimeno and Polvese Island by ferry.
- Spoleto
- Perugia deserves at least a full day's visit, including museums in the city centre
There are excellent places to try Umbrian cuisine, it really depends on what you want to eat.
In Perugia there are both trattorias and delicious local street food places (La bottega di Perugia, Daje). As restaurants there I recommend Al Giurista, Osteria a Priori, Stella. Good pizzerias in the area include : Marghereat, I cento Passi, Filo d'olio, Officine Bartolini.A classic local food is Torta al Testo, but don't get it at tourist chains like Il Testone, it's not worth it. Bar Molino Centumbrie, just outside Perugia, won Best bar of Italy award, it's amazing for cornetti, pizza and to buy local produces.
Assisi is very expensive, but you can eat well there too .
Elena Eugeni l’osteria a priori purtroppo è scaduta tantissimo, non so se era per Umbria jazz ma ci sono stata recentemente e male male ￼

I searched and searched. Cheaper days to fly were on Mondays. Cheapest time to buy was 6:30am Tuesday morning. We are flying North Carolina to Venice returning home from Florence. $1000 round trip per person. Delta airlines

text: Gifts for family hosting our daughter and her friend? Hi our daughter and friend are heading to Italy. They are staying with a friend who was an exchange student last year here in Canada. He and his family have planned a beautiful itinerary for the girls. What can we pack as a gift? We will of course put some Canadian maple syrup.. can we pack a bottle of Crown Royal? Suggestions please. 🥰

comments.comment_text: Did the exchange student enjoy any Canadian specific good or candy? What about a mug, tea towel or the like from Canada? If your daughter is under aged, I would check about the Crown Royal. That may not be allowed.
I love bringing Sortilege liquor (maple syrup liquor). Not sure if it's available in every province though. Also certain chocolate bars like coffee crisp which are usually only found in Canada!

Perhaps a picture or art piece as a memento of his time in Canada along with a few small Canadian treats. Your daughter and friend could buy a gift certificate in Italy for them to a favourite restaurant or theatre play.
What about a small soapstone carving, ensuring that it was created by an actual indigenous artist and not made in china?
Buy flowers when you leave
Yes but do not put in hand luggage. How about Oka cheese? Costco sells them 2 in a pack. Nice gift
Roots clothing or muskoka bear wear clothing
Is your daughter of legal age? If so buy both at duty free. If not I don't think she can carry alcohol. We were in Portugal a couple of years ago they loved the 🇨🇦 maple syrup

Thank you everyone!!
We went with roots, beaver canoe and maple syrup 🤩🇨🇦🤩

Ciao! for us italians is customary when we are guests of someone bring a tray of sweets or rotisserie, she could take a tray of what she prefers directly here and maybe even a bottle of wine! there is no better gift than good food, if she have already taken some gifts from canada, well! Even a cup or some magnet from your city would be nice
Smoked salmon is always good and doesn’t have to be refrigerated

When my daughter went to visit my other daughter who was studying abroad in Italy, there were a bunch of foods that the young girl who lived in the house had never tried and she had requested. I don’t know if they have these in Canada, but she has requested Fluff, Cheetos and Reeces peanut butter cups from what I remember. Maybe there is something that isn’t so easy to come by in Italy.
You can get crown Royal in Italy.
Something made of maple. A serving dish ir cheese board. They love wood in Europe.

text: Question about transferring flights and customs. If we fly to Rome from the US then connect to anywhere else in Italy the same day, do we need to go through customs and recheck bags before connecting? Thanks!

comments.comment_text: Are you flying direct to Rome? If you are then you will go though customs in Rome and that’s it. If you have a connecting flight, then you will though customs at that country’s custom control. I’m trying to remember if I had to go through customs when I arrived at my final destination.
Not if you’re traveling within Italy.
Yes

You always clear customs at the first airport of arrival in the European Union (for instance, if you fly NY-Rome via Paris, you clear customs in Paris). What you don’t do in Europe is to pick up your bags and recheck them. They are sent to your final destination.
The only exception, of course, is if you have booked separate flights with different airlines.
You will go through customs when you land in Rome.
